caption_original:
Effective immediately, vessels travelling in the western Gulf of St. Lawrence are mandated to reduce their speed to a maximum of 10 knots. The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than 20 metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area.

 
Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements.  Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: http://ow.ly/n5qc30el2Kw

Transport and Infrastructure in Canada

The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area. Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements. Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: Transport and Infrastructure in Canada

caption_original:
8 million metric tonnes of plastic end up in the ocean every year, roughly the weight of sixty CN Towers. This plastic is ingested by marine animals and is responsible for the deaths of endangered species like the Leatherback turtle.
You can do your part in protecting our oceans and marine wildlife. Consider avoiding disposable items like plastic bags and using eco-friendly alternatives like reusable bags. Learn about other ways you can make an impact: http://ow.ly/brFA30e4WpZ

caption_original: Narwhals have arrived in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut! Several thousand are there to feed. Our researchers are tagging a few to learn more about their habits and how we can better protect them. Discover more on the “unicorns of the sea” here: http://ow.ly/MEdD30ei69v

caption_original: Calling all Canadians, help the whales! Some of our whales are facing increased pressures from human activity. The Government of Canada is looking into how to recover the populations of three endangered whales: the Southern Resident Killer Whale, North Atlantic Right Whale and St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga. Have your say to help these whales. http://ow.ly/wOWz30egqmm

The Government of Canada is looking into how to recover the populations of three endangered whales: the Southern Resident Killer Whale, North Atlantic Right Whale and St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga. Have your say to help these whales.

caption_original: Today our scientists returned from a week of exploring the Gulf of St. Lawrence with Oceana Canada and ROPOS, a cutting edge remotely operated vehicle. Together, we surveyed the diversity and ecology of four different areas of the Gulf’s sea floor. Take a look at some of the amazing species we encountered during our expedition! http://ow.ly/r44E30eNnxE

caption_original:
We are taking action on the recovery, protection and conservation of the endangered North Atlantic Right Whale. The deaths of the whales in the Gulf of St. Lawrence this summer is an unprecedented situation.  
 
We are conducting necropsies on the deceased whales with partners to learn the cause of death and determine next steps. We closed some snow crab fisheries early and other fixed gear fisheries have either been restricted or have been delayed. We have notified fishermen to stay on high alert and report any sightings. We are regularly conducting surveillance flights to monitor for whales. The Canadian Coast Guard is asking shipping vessels entering our waters to decrease their speed until further notice.  

Learn more about what we are doing to protect the North Atlantic Right whales: http://ow.ly/MVlC30e8Nu4

We are regularly conducting surveillance flights to monitor for whales. The Canadian Coast Guard is asking shipping vessels entering our waters to decrease their speed until further notice. Learn more about what we are doing to protect the North Atlantic Right whales:

caption_original: Teamwork! The Canadian Coast Guard and our scientists work together to make science at sea happen. The Coast Guard recently deployed drifting buoys for our ocean research team while they were heading to the Arctic aboard the CCGS Terry Fox. Those buoys will transmit location data to help us understand ocean currents and to better forecast drifting icebergs, thus ensuring a safer navigation in the Arctic. http://ow.ly/LaPP30e3Laa

caption_original: Lobsters are the largest and longest-living crustaceans on the planet. The largest lobster ever caught was found in Nova Scotia weighing over 44 pounds and is believed to have been over 100 years old! http://ow.ly/KQJ630ezlla

caption_original: We are monitoring the Atlantic salmon situation off the coast of Washington State. We will conduct stream surveys in areas closest to the U.S. border to monitor for any escaped Atlantic salmon. Canada has rigorous aquaculture regulations. Our Atlantic Salmon Watch Program monitors British Columbia’s rivers for escaped Atlantic salmon. Anyone who believes they have caught an Atlantic salmon in B.C. waters should keep the fish and report it by calling the toll-free reporting line at 1-800-811-6010. Our complete statement here: http://ow.ly/ZOYh30eERds

caption_original: This summer, our Fishery Officers patrolled the Western Arctic aboard the CCGS Sir Wilfrid Laurier watching for possible Fisheries Act and Oceans Act violations. This inaugural patrol of Canada’s newest Marine Protected Area, Anguniaqvia niqiqyuam supports the protection of Canada’s fishery resources. Officers also surveyed the first Arctic Marine Protected Area, Tarium Niryutait. Learn more about our nation’s diverse and unique protected areas here: http://ow.ly/TRoo30elJkI

caption_original:
Canada’s network of small craft harbours is the backbone of the fishing industry and the livelihood of more than 42,000 workers. Commercial fishermen can count on the work, dedication and effort of 5,000 volunteers across the country; people like Denis Gallant, seen is this photo during an announcement in Grande-Digue, N.B., earlier this month with the Minister of Fisheries, Oceans and the Canadian Coast Guard, the Honourable Dominic LeBlanc. 

The Government of Canada announced it is investing close to $15,7 million this year to carry out projects at several small craft harbours in New Brunswick. http://ow.ly/TaxM30eomXl

caption_original: Help us protect the whales by keeping a safe distance this summer! Whale watching is an exciting boating activity enjoyed by many. With this excitement, comes responsibility - when we get too close, approach too fast, or make too much noise, we can disrupt their activities, cause them unnecessary stress, and put their lives in danger. http://ow.ly/Cxqh30e3Haa

caption_original:
British Columbia’s Fraser River salmon returns are low this year and conservation is our first priority. After conservation, Indigenous groups have priority access to fish for food, social, and ceremonial uses.  
One of the keys to protecting the future of salmon stocks is effective monitoring and enforcement to detect and deter illegal fishing activity by all user groups. Our Fishery Officers are actively monitoring and enforcing all fishing activity using a variety of methods, including aerial, ocean, river, on-the-ground, night and undercover patrols. Find out more about how we manage Fraser River fisheries to protect salmon: http://ow.ly/vQfb30eJ6uP

caption_original: What can the Beaufort Gyre – a unique portion of the Arctic Ocean – tell us about the impacts of climate change? A lot! Our oceanographer, Sarah Zimmermann, explains Canada’s contributions to the Joint Ocean Ice Studies – an international expedition that monitors oceanographic conditions in the Arctic. Since 2003, this long term study has been offering real insight into how the Arctic is changing and what this means for Canadians and the world. Learn more about how we support Arctic Ocean monitoring in advance of World Oceans Day in the Arctic this Friday! http://ow.ly/mFCD30ebdJx

Since , this long term study has been offering real insight into how the Arctic is changing and what this means for Canadians and the world. Learn more about how we support Arctic Ocean monitoring in advance of World Oceans Day in the Arctic this Friday!

caption_original: The recreational cod fishery is open this weekend in Newfoundland and Labrador. When you return to the wharf with your catch, you may meet a student with DFO's Citizen Cod 2017 project. They're collecting information that will be used in scientific stock assessments. Dr. Ben Davis explains why the program is important.

caption_original: Our scientists have identified what actions are needed to help the Southern Resident Killer Whale, St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga and the North Atlantic Right Whale. While we know the actions that need to be taken, we also know that some of these actions may not be easy. We want to hear your ideas on how we can best work together to make this happen. http://ow.ly/Y78930eoPa2

caption_original: We purchased 6 new gliders to better monitor changes in Canada’s oceans. They will help gather data on water temperature, salinity, and oxygen levels. Gliders are semi-autonomous vehicles that can travel thousands of kilometers and dive hundreds of meters on a single charge from a small, but powerful battery.  Some can even track marine life like krill and whales. Find out more about our ocean science and climate change research: http://ow.ly/hyhO30eoGuX

caption_original: Five of our scientists are on board the CCGS Henry Larsen en route to the Barrow Strait in the high Arctic. They will be learning more about water and ice conditions.

caption_original:
Killer whales are a vocal bunch. They use clicking sounds as echolocation to track down prey. They can also talk and even sing to each other with whistles and squeaks. These sounds are so complex that each pod has its own distinct language! 
We want your feedback on how to better protect the Southern Resident Killer Whale. Have your say now: http://ow.ly/o94U30egsv2

caption_original: One of our annual scientific surveys takes us to places like the Scotian Shelf, Bay of Fundy, Georges Bank & the Gully off the coast of Nova Scotia to collect samples of different invertebrates species. These surveys help scientists learn about the variety of species in the Atlantic Ocean.

caption_original: The narwhal research camp team in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, launched the BRUV, an underwater remote camera. The BRUV sits on the ocean floor and is equipped with bait, a camera and a high-power light that can withstand the extreme cold and pressure of the deep Arctic sea. It films animals attracted by the bait and acts as our eyes in the deep waters of Tremblay Sound.

caption_original: Many of the leatherback sea turtles seen in our waters nest in Trinidad and Tobago. Every year, our Sea Turtle Biologist Mike James travels there to work with local conservation groups to collect data from nesting leatherback sea turtles. His work enables remote detecting of turtles on the beach so research can be done throughout the nesting season. Last week, his Trinidad and Tobago colleagues joined him in Halifax to discuss how they can further this collaboration and observe research activities underway off Nova Scotia.
caption_cleaned: Many of the leatherback sea turtles seen in our waters nest in Trinidad and Tobago. Every year, our Sea Turtle Biologist Mike James travels there to work with local conservation groups to collect data from nesting leatherback sea turtles. His work enables remote detecting of turtles on the beach so research can be done throughout the nesting season. Last week, his Trinidad and Tobago colleagues joined him in Halifax to discuss how they can further this collaboration and observe research activities underway off Nova Scotia.

caption_original: Weighing one and a half tonnes, the Atlantic walrus may look clumsy and slow-moving on land. But in the water, they are smooth and graceful swimmers. They have poor vision but they are still excellent at hunting, using their sensitive whiskers to detect prey and strong suction to swallow them. The Atlantic walrus prefers cold waters and there may still be up to several thousand walruses in Canadian waters. http://ow.ly/UlWs30eJiJt

The Atlantic walrus prefers cold waters and there may still be up to several thousand walruses in Canadian waters.

caption_original: Did you know that both Fisheries and Oceans Canada and Transport and Infrastructure in Canada  have aerial surveillance programs? Recently, the two teams collaborated to monitor fishing activities in Arctic waters to ensure all regulations are being followed. The Greenland halibut and shrimp fisheries off of Baffin Island, Nunavut are being extensively monitored this year.

caption_original: Ryan Critch is this summer's DFO Newfoundland & Labrador Communications Intern. He says being a DFO Intern has been an incredible experience, “I’ve gotten to work with some pretty amazing people, and the work I’m doing is relevant to my field of study.”  He is learning all about communications, and having fun too. “It doesn’t get much better than that for a summer intern,” he says. The region is lucky to have seven interns working this summer in I.T., Science, Policy, and Conservation and Protection. Find information on student job opportunities and how to apply here: http://ow.ly/7mhI30ebdd4

caption_original:
Since 1950, our scientists have been monitoring “Line P” – a stretch of ocean that spans over 1,500 km off the southern coast of Vancouver Island. We monitor this area to observe changes and assess risks that may impact marine ecosystems and the West Coast communities and economies that rely on them.
Get the latest on our entire ocean monitoring work. http://ow.ly/xrrW30e7gqK

caption_original: Ice Invasion! Wind and currents brought enough ice into Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, to temporarily stall our narwhal research. So the team took the time to concentrate on fish ecosystems instead.
caption_cleaned: Ice Invasion! Wind and currents brought enough ice into Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, to temporarily stall our narwhal research. So the team took the time to concentrate on fish ecosystems instead.

caption_original: Did you know that the establishment of marine protected areas is one of the measures taken by the Government of Canada to protect and preserve our oceans? Marine protected areas are geographically delimited marine zones that are managed for the purpose of conserving and protecting: marine species – including endangered species – and their populations; diversity of the ecosystems on which these species depend; representative marine environments; as well as unique locations such as submarine canyons and hydrothermal vents. They can allow certain present and future activities by taking account of their impacts on protected ecological characteristics. To better understand what marine protected areas are: http://ow.ly/NInc30esAzg

Marine protected areas are geographically delimited marine zones that are managed for the purpose of conserving and protecting: marine species – including endangered species – and their populations; diversity of the ecosystems on which these species depend; representative marine environments; as well as unique locations such as submarine canyons and hydrothermal vents. They can allow certain present and future activities by taking account of their impacts on protected ecological characteristics. To better understand what marine protected areas are:

caption_original:
Located in the eastern Gaspé Peninsula in Quebec, the American Bank was selected in 2011 as a potential site for a new Marine Protected Area. In-depth knowledge of the site is an essential prerequisite for creating a Marine Protected Area. We know the site has many assets: diversity of its habitats; presence of many commercially valuable species and species at risk; as well as significant potential as a feeding ground for various species of fish and marine mammals. http://ow.ly/dADN30eoIQY 

The establishment of the American Bank as a Marine Protected Area should promote the productivity and diversity of commercially fished species as well as the recovery of species at risk.
caption_cleaned: Located in the eastern Gaspé Peninsula in Quebec, the American Bank was selected in as a potential site for a new Marine Protected Area. In-depth knowledge of the site is an essential prerequisite for creating a Marine Protected Area. We know the site has many assets: diversity of its habitats; presence of many commercially valuable species and species at risk; as well as significant potential as a feeding ground for various species of fish and marine mammals. The establishment of the American Bank as a Marine Protected Area should promote the productivity and diversity of commercially fished species as well as the recovery of species at risk.

caption_original: Arctic Char are very common in the Tremblay Sound, Nunavut ecosystem. As part of ecosystem research, some were tagged to help us understand their movements, including spawning migrations, and their role in the food web. Researchers are pleased with the success of the Arctic Char tagging; many of those tagged made their way to Milne Inlet (60km away) in as little as three days! http://ow.ly/vUAT30eJBgN

Researchers are pleased with the success of the Arctic Char tagging; many of those tagged made their way to Milne Inlet (60km away) in as little as three days!

caption_original: The green crab recently made headlines. The potential consumption of its meat has recently been touted as an option on how to limit the spread of this invasive species in Canadian waters. Several other options are also being studied. Learn more about this species found abundantly in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and how to report sightings here: http://ow.ly/eJuV30eoXqE

caption_original: Whales feed under water but must return to the surface to breathe. During each dive, they have a choice to make: stay as long as possible under water or take short dives and resurface often. Learn how they choose: http://ow.ly/vekX30e5sf3
caption_cleaned: Whales feed under water but must return to the surface to breathe. During each dive, they have a choice to make: stay as long as possible under water or take short dives and resurface often. Learn how they choose:

caption_original: This summer, we are crossing the Northwest Passage, the route connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans through Canada’s Arctic waters. We will be collaborating with the Polar Research Institute of China’s researchers aboard their vessel to study the Arctic environment and gather hydrographic data to help map the seafloor.
caption_cleaned: This summer, we are crossing the Northwest Passage, the route connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans through Canada’s Arctic waters. We will be collaborating with the Polar Research Institute of China’s researchers aboard their vessel to study the Arctic environment and gather hydrographic data to help map the seafloor.

caption_original: Shark sightings and accidental interactions are common in Newfoundland and Labrador waters and the public plays a vital role in shark research. If you see a shark, dead or alive, take a photo. Note the date and location and send it to Carolyn.Miri@dfo-mpo.gc.ca. But do it safely. No shark selfies! Don’t bring the shark aboard your boat. Its skin is like sandpaper and the edges of the fins are as sharp as filleting knives. Wear heavy gloves and use bolt cutters to snap off the hook and line. http://ow.ly/VAwz30eJ7UR
caption_cleaned: Shark sightings and accidental interactions are common in Newfoundland and Labrador waters and the public plays a vital role in shark research. If you see a shark, dead or alive, take a photo. Note the date and location and send it to Carolyn.Miri-mpo.gc.ca. But do it safely. No shark selfies! Don’t bring the shark aboard your boat. Its skin is like sandpaper and the edges of the fins are as sharp as filleting knives. Wear heavy gloves and use bolt cutters to snap off the hook and line.

caption_original: Humpback whales are the noisiest and most imaginative of whales when it comes to song. They sing complex, eerie and beautiful ballads that last between 10 and 20 minutes and can be heard more than 20 miles away. If you’re lucky, you’ll spot a humpback whale while enjoying the Pacific coast.  If you see one, remember to slow down, keep your distance, approach from the side, and keep clear of their path. http://ow.ly/WJhd30ezm7a
caption_cleaned: Humpback whales are the noisiest and most imaginative of whales when it comes to song. They sing complex, eerie and beautiful ballads that last between and minutes and can be heard more than miles away. If you’re lucky, you’ll spot a humpback whale while enjoying the Pacific coast. If you see one, remember to slow down, keep your distance, approach from the side, and keep clear of their path.

caption_original: Have your say on how we can better protect three species of endangered whales http://www.letstalkwhales.ca/

caption_original: Since the arrival of our SeaExplorer gliders this spring, scientists have been training & testing on missions in the Bedford Basin off Nova Scotia. Gliders are unmanned oceanographic tools that help our scientists measure and monitor our oceans. Scientists at our Bedford Institute of Oceanography will be taking the gliders on their first official science mission this fall. To learn more about our gliders – visit the BIO EXPO this September. http://ow.ly/IyNC30eAZzY

caption_original: New salmon smolts are sorted for an aquaculture study, at our St. Andrews Biological Station in New Brunswick. The study is to increase sea lice resistance in Atlantic Salmon which will improve the sustainability of Canadian aquaculture industry. http://ow.ly/hks330egn4N

caption_original:
British Columbia inshore rockfish numbers are low. Since 2002, catch restrictions, fishery monitoring, stock assessment programs, and Rockfish Conservation Areas have been established throughout BC’s coast to help to protect and conserve this fragile species. 

We need your help! Before going fishing, find out where BC’s Rockfish Conservation Areas are located and what you can and can’t do within these areas. http://ow.ly/W5uk30ezdYm

caption_original:
You’re invited to provide comments on the future of the Freshwater Fish Marketing Corporation. The province of Manitoba will be withdrawing from the Freshwater Fish Marketing Act later this year. We invite freshwater fishers and all affected stakeholders to share their views. 

We’ve been travelling to communities across Manitoba, Saskatchewan and the Northwest Territories to hear from you. You can also tell us what you think online until September 29th. We look forward to hearing from you! www.letstalkfreshwater.ca

We look forward to hearing from you!

caption_original: Whales may be harmed by many threats in our waters. In our Let’s Talk Whales online conversation, have your say and help address some of the key threats whales face. http://ow.ly/weJe30eJc2G

Shellfish safety: making shellfish delicious, not dangerous.

caption_original: Fisheries officers and Aboriginal and contracted fishery guardians regularly patrol rivers across Newfoundland and Labrador, monitoring salmon and trout angling. It’s important to remember all rivers on the island of Newfoundland are closed to retention of salmon. http://ow.ly/wIpq30eozIN

caption_original: Ever seen a fish climb a ladder? caption_original:
Corals, sponges, and octopi…
We’re hoping to catch a glimpse of some of the amazing marine animals that call the Gulf of St. Lawrence home! We’re on the Canadian Coast Guard’s Martha L. Black working with Oceana Canada to study and capture footage of previously unexplored habitats of this biologically diverse region. Tune in to our live stream! http://ow.ly/neVD30eIYlE

caption_original: We take the recovery, protection and conservation of the various endangered species in the St. Lawrence River very seriously. In addition to safeguarding these species, we are also working to protect all marine mammals in these waters. When observing seals, whales, porpoises or dolphins, keep your distance! Know what to do by consulting our best practices for watching marine mammals: http://ow.ly/E8JY30eoqlk

caption_original:
Fishing in BC this summer? We need your help. If you catch a Coho or Chinook salmon with a healed scar in place of the adipose fin (the small fin on lower back), remove the head and bring it to a Salmon Head Recovery Depot in your area: http://ow.ly/Wlwr30e7pvL 
You’ll be helping us evaluate the health of the salmon stock and we’ll send you information about your catch.

If you catch a Coho or Chinook salmon with a healed scar in place of the adipose fin (the small fin on lower back), remove the head and bring it to a Salmon Head Recovery Depot in your area: You’ll be helping us evaluate the health of the salmon stock and we’ll send you information about your catch.

caption_original:
For beluga whales, the St. Lawrence Estuary is a critical living environment. This is where they are born, live, eat, and socialize. The St. Lawrence belugas are endangered. Help them recover by behaving responsibly and reducing disturbances. #Beluga400m If you see a beluga whale: Keep your distance, slow down, move at least 400 metres away.

For more information about best practices for navigation around beluga whales: http://ow.ly/UK5q30dMQFg
And about the Regulations in the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park: http://ow.ly/il8g30dMQJM

caption_original: Excited to experience the solar eclipse happening across the country this afternoon? If you’re planning on going out on the water to enjoy this cool phenomenon, do it safely. Be sure to stop your boat and stay alert for others on the water. Remember, the Canadian Coast Guard is here to help! http://ow.ly/VJU630ewnoR

caption_original:
Ice delays have the science team working on experimental approaches to tracking and understanding narwhal and their ecosystem in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut. We’re finding ways to turn tracking studies into community-based research projects. Summer gathering areas like Tremblay Sound are well-known to Inuit, and Inuit researchers are excited by long-term research opportunities.

This week, the team has been working to install a series of Very High Frequency receiving stations in Tremblay Sound. These stations will allow us to follow tagged narwhals and better understand their behaviour. 

Photos: © Troy Neale/Vancouver Aquarium
caption_cleaned: Ice delays have the science team working on eerimental approaches to tracking and understanding narwhal and their ecosystem in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut. We’re finding ways to turn tracking studies into community-based research projects. Summer gathering areas like Tremblay Sound are well-known to Inuit, and Inuit researchers are excited by long-term research opportunities. This week, the team has been working to install a series of Very High Frequency receiving stations in Tremblay Sound. These stations will allow us to follow tagged narwhals and better understand their behaviour. Photos: © Troy Neale/Vancouver Aquarium
